channel.description: our association seeks to make accessible , the means of learning authentic knowledge of islam, inviting others to it and promoting its peaceful, holistic and righteous way of life amongst all sectors of the Gambian population.

item.title: Sample Page
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
This is an example page. It's different from a blog post because it will stay in one place and will show up in your site navigation (in most themes). Most people start with an About page that introduces them to potential site visitors. It might say something like this:
Hi there! I'm a bike messenger by day, aspiring actor by night, and this is my blog. I live in Los Angeles, have a great dog named Jack, and I like piña coladas. (And gettin' caught in the rain.)
...or something like this:
The XYZ Doohickey Company was founded in 1971, and has been providing quality doohickies to the public ever since. Located in Gotham City, XYZ employs over 2,000 people and does all kinds of awesome things for the Gotham community.
As a new WordPress user, you should go to your dashboard to delete this page and create new pages for your content. Have fun!

item.title: آل الشيخ : اطلاق وصف الشخص بالكافر أمر خطير، وخاصة إذا صدر بغير علم او أهلية شرعية
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
حذّر سماحة الشيخ عبدالعزيز بن عبدالله آل الشيخ مفتي عام المملكة، رئيس هيئة كبار العلماء من التكفير والتبديع والتفسيق للمسلم بغير علم وبدون دراية، لما يترتب على ذلك من آثار خطيرة على الفرد والمجتمع والدين، وقال : ان اطلاق وصف الشخص بالكافر أمر خطير، وخاصة إذا صدر بغير علم او أهلية شرعية، مضيفا أن هناك من يستسهل اطلاق وصف “يا كافر ” و”يا عدو الله” على بعض الناس وهذا أمر خطير، مشيرا الى من يقال له “يا كافر” لابد من التأكد ان هذا الشخص يخالف الاسلام، وعدو لدينه ولشرعه، وطالب سماحته بعدم التهاون في اطلاق هذا الوصف لخطورة ذلك .
وتناول سماحة المفتي العام في خطبة الجمعة التي ألقاها أمس بالجامع الكبير بمنطقة قصر الحكم بالرياض ظاهرة التكفير وأخطارها محذرًا منها وما يترتب عليها من اخطار عظيمة، فضررها على الفرد الذي يحكم عليه بالكفر أنه مخلّد في النار ويفرّق بينه وبين زوجته واولاده ولا يدفن في مقابر المسلمين، إنه لأمر عظيم جدا .. كيف يقبل ان تطلق بلا دليل ولا رؤية،
اما عن خطرها على المجتمع فإنها تشتت وتفرّق الكلمة وتحدث البلبلة وتغلق باب الدعوة التي هي بالتي هي أحسن، فالداعية همّه نشر الاسلام والدعوة الى الله، وتوضيح الطريق الصحيح لا التكفير والتفسيق والتبديع، فالداعية عليه ان ينصح ويوضح ويبيّن صحيح الدين ويقيم الحجة على المخطىء،
وقال المفتي العام : إن الذين يكفّرون الناس بلا دليل ولا حجة ولا برهان ولا تثبيت يشوّهون صورة الاسلام، ويؤدون الى سفك الدماء لأنهم حكموا بالكفر على أناس فأحلّوا دماءهم واعراضهم واموالهم واهدروا حقوقهم،بلا علم وهذا مذهب الخوارج في القديم والحديث الذين يكفّرون بالذنب والخطيئة، والخوارج أساءوا للإسلام بهذا المذهب الباطل فما رفعوا للاسلام راية ولا حققوا له أي فائدة بل أساءوا إليه، وهم يخالفون مذهب أهل السنة والجماعة، الذي لا يكفّر مسلمًا بمعصية، وحذّر سماحته من التكفير بالهوى وظاهر الأمر دون دليل شرعي من الكتاب والسنة ولا تثبّت،
وأكد المفتي العام : على المسلم أن يحفظ لسانه من النطق بكلمة كافر أو عدو الله، وطالب بتوعية المعلمين والمعلمات والخطباء وأهل الإعلام بهذا الخطر ومعالجة هذه الظاهرة، وأن يكون همّ الداعية إقامة الحجة والتعريف بالدعوة وإزالة الشبهة، وعدم الانخداع ببعض من يدّعون العلم والدعوة الذين يقعون في تفسيق الناس ورميهم بالفسق والكفر، وحذّر من أهل الضلال والافساد،
وقال سماحته: لا يكون التكفير والتبديع والتفسيق شعارًا لنا من غير علم ولا حجة ولا منهج، مؤكدا ان الحكم الشرعي لا يكون إلّا من العلماء وأصحاب العلم ولا يكون من غير المؤهلين .
نقله مشكوراً المشارك أبو عبد الرحمن الشرحي.

item.title: Donate
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
Al-Atharee welcomes all donations to support our work. If you would like to make a one-off donation please complete the Single Donation Form. Alternatively, you can commit to regular donations by completing the Standing Order Form. Post your completed forms to .......... We will not use this information to contact you except in relation to your donations to Al-Atharee, and we will not pass on your personal details without your consent. Thank you for your support.
Enter Amount to donate:
GBP

item.title: About Us
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
Al Atharee Gambia is a Charitable Association, Registered in The Gambia West Africa [Reg.No.1200/2004]. Its activities were initiated by a retired Muslim couple, from the U.K. with backgrounds in Public Health Administration & Education.

Initially on taking up residence in 2003, the couple were shocked by the widespread grinding poverty, 85% illiteracy, rampant Malaria, numerous Orphans, lack of general knowledge concerning disease prevention and the common confused beliefs and sparse understanding of Islam, though it be the religion professed by 95% of the population.

On providing Community Literacy classes in both urban and rural districts, they perceived a mounting interest and willingness to learn, was growing rapidly around them. They sought the advice of a well respected knowledgeable Imam in The Gambia, Jibril Kujabi, who directed one of his mature students, Muhammad Jadama, to assist their efforts as a Community Teacher.

Jadama proved an effective teacher, especially attracting youth, many of whom had been orphaned as infants and thereby unable to attend school.Then on initiating an Orphan Support Project, made possible by Zakat from friends, we were advised to form and register a charitable organisation. Its name, “Al Atharee” was chosen to indicate its humanitarian educational projects as having been founded upon the teachings of The Quran, and authentic Sunnah, of Muhammad, the final Prophet of Allah, sallallahu alaihi wassalam.

Al Atharee Association has a Memorandum of Understanding with the Ministry of Social Welfare, in respect of our engaging with Orphans and concern for their education, social and moral wellbeing. Also we are registered with the Supreme Islamic Council and Consult with the Gambian Islamic Arabic Educational Secretariat. Our projects continue to receive commendations by these official bodies and requested by communities, especially in the more remote regions.

Since 2009 Al Atharee Association has increased its pro-active membership, which at its core is a Community Teaching Team of 7 Gambians. They have successfully completed their studies at Medina University, KSA and include Imam Ismail Jatta; Imam Alhasan Fatty; Dr F Jawla; Dr B Ceesay; and Dr A.K. Sillah, who also gained much field experience in Niger. Muhammad Jadama is currently applying for a Masters Program at Medina al Munawarra.

All members participate on a voluntary basis and share the founding vision, to enable The Gambia as a whole, to more easily access the pure knowledge of The Quran & Sunnah of Prophet Muhammad, sallallahu alaihi wassalam, and implement that learning, in order to bring about long lasting improvements in their health, education and peaceful future prospects, Insha’Allah.

item.title: The Gambia
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
The Gambia, officially the Republic of the Gambia and commonly known as Gambia by its residents, is a country in Western Africa. It is the smallest country on mainland Africa, bordered to the north, east, and south by Senegal, with a non-polluted coast line on the Atlantic Ocean in the west. The Gambia's present boundaries were defined in 1889 after an agreement between Britain and France concerning their continued lucrative usage of the River Gambia. Therefore its borders are roughly parallel to the path of the Gambia River, the nation's namesake, which flows through the country's center and empties into the Atlantic Ocean.The Gambia is almost 11,300 km² [4' 200 sq miles] and is considered to be the smallest African nation, with an estimated population of 1,600,000. Banjul is the Gambia's capital, but the largest populated urban district and transport interconnection is Serrekunda.
The climate of the Gambia is tropical with two seasons. the dry season spans 8 months from late October to late June. From March daily averge temperatures rise to over 38* C and there is sparse herbage for the roaming animals to feed. Everybody tries to plant shortcrops in or nearby their compounds, in small bush clearances, but this depends on whether they can access enough water for twice daily irrigation. In May the country is awash with a massive mango and cashew nut harvest which is picked manually and much is exported by road and ship to North Senegal.
The heavy rain season occurs between July and October sometimes extended to November. This is the main farming season for the staple crops of rice, cassava, sweet potato, corn, cous and beans which are grown for local consumption. Also peanut is planted near the end of the wet season and after local processing for its oil and some sold in local markets, the remainder is exported as the main cash crop. The wet season is visibly welcomed in the country; its as if the whole population gets into a whirl of excited communal activity with the organisation of many truckloads of exuberant youths being moved from town to village to help communities in their ploughing and planting activities. Working tractors are a luxury and oxen pulled ploughs are few, so much is still laboriously done by manual tools, which are locally made. Yet, as the torrential rains soak the backs of the long lines of field workers, one can hear them sing while they labour so intensively. In 2010 there was a marked and publicly commended increase in the population's response to the call of the current Muslim President, for ' Food Self - Sufficiency', especially in rice the staple diet. Maybe more people are appreciating his own active example in that respect, who, also as a farmer himself, is often seen working alongside his family and community on the lands at Kanilai. He is also a keen promoter of agricultural studies and programmes in the schools and media.
Nevertheless, the frequent storms also bring difficulty to many, as mud block houses are often demolished and rooves are blown off whilst the local media give warnings to people and vehicles, to keep clear of flooded rural areas, particularily as crocodiles and snakes are an additional danger. Malaria and Dysentery too, which are rampant throughout the year, are greatly increased in the rain season, causing hospitals to become overcrowded and understaffed and many children orphaned.
The history of a country or region is important to be known and studied with its evidences. by both its present day indigenous population as well as those beyond its borders, so that lessons may be learned, repetition of evil practices be avoided, injustices rectified where possible, at least in modern day perceptions, and the righteous behaviour and development of a society to be recognized and appreciated.
Therefore it is enough to be said in this article that The Gambia, as part of the Senegambia region, between the 15th -19th centuries did suffer relentless decimation of their population by the enforcement of the cruel trans-atlantic slave trade initiated by the governing bodies of Portugal, then France and Britain of those times. Without a doubt this well known highly lucrative trade in human cargo became by default, the mainstay in fiscal, human and technological resources, which enabled the rapid material development and empire building of the said European powers and later the Americas themselves.
Unfortunately the legitimate trade in gold dust, ivory, spices, corn, peppers, gum, wax and hides formerly traded on the River Gambia, could not compete with it and it has been estimated from documented archives, that from the total 11 million african people enslaved during that period, about 6 million people were shipped out of the Sene-Gambia region, utilising the Gambia River, which was able to bear sea-faring ships upto 200 km inland, which provided the key to the establishment of a Slave Colony. Whoever else saw some short term advantage in this matter it is clear that without the instigation and organisation of the European powers, of those times, such an extensive and long term international export market could never have existed.
The 'Abolition of Slavery Bill' may have eventully stopped actual human trafficking on the River Gambia, but there are other ways of perpetuating the enslaved mentality. For instance, when doors are kept locked to international trading. How come, ships could sail across the Atlantic to the Americas when the cargo was African humans but when it came to African goods -there were, and still are, no trans-atlantic trade routes or supply of ships. Neither where there any direct return routes for the 'emancipated' slaves. Would such, not have been a suitable form of reparation, by those who had pricking consciences and more enlightened later generations could have taken up?
Mentioning these historical events is to remind visitors to this part of the world, that whatever might be seen on the side of the road in the new urban areas or deep in the bush and wetlands, does not only belong to present times but is a long term effect from the past. When the best of the generations in terms of those imbued with a strong and vibrant knowledge of their religion, Islam and technological inventions, where ripped out from their usual residence - it was bound to leave a gaping cavity which the aged or disabled remnants left behind, found hard to still cling onto, especially as the places of islamic learning and libraries were also destroyed in the capturing of the slaves.
Nevertheless, without a doubt, the peoples of the Gambia should be acclaimed for remaining so attached to their birthright -Islaam. For despite the repeated ravaging of their population by slave traders and the ensuing poverty, the Gambian Muslim population did not leave off the calling of the Adhan, the attendance to 5 times daily Salat in every settlement and the observance of Ramadan.
Indeed present day Gambia is a credit in the Muslim world. Every child in Muslim families daily attends "Quranic Dara" whether or not, they attend other formal schooling. Also Arabic Institutes continue to spring up to retain the pure classical Arabic language and many male youth are keen to continue their studies in Mauritania or Arabia to obtain Degrees and Doctorates.
Yet the drive to make the present better and the future objectives attainable is not restricted to the preservation of their religious roots but extends to enabling the country, hopefully to grow upon those roots, to become an equal or advanced participant in the international arena. The visionary construction of a well planned network of surfaced roads with drainage, connecting the agricultural districts and fisheries with the urban markets, sea port at Banjul and air port has only occurred in the last 15 years, even though Independence and joining the Commonwealth, was attained in 1965. Without a doubt, these roads have contributed greatly to not only enabling ourselves and others to perform a variety of charitable works, but has definitively aided the establishment of widespread schooling, health education and strengthened the economy throughout the country.
Nevertheless, for the visitor there are still strange contrasting sights between the commercial districts with tall glass banks, streams of traffic and bore holes providing piped water and within 30 minutes drive, the palm leaf thatching of mud brick homes in the rural areas with girls pulling buckets of water from wells, children playing freely between the compounds and rarely a vehicle in sight. In many respects having lived here for 8 years we think the Gambia to be a blessed country with beautiful natural environment, a rich variety of song birds, flora and fauna, where domestic and wild animals are encouraged to roam freely and its inhabitants are not suffering from any industrial pollutants, which have destroyed so many other parts of the world. Also the Gambia is virtually crime free in respect of rape, murders, paedophilia whilst the current government continues to have Zero Tolerance towards drugs.
We pray that Allah, the Lord of all the Worlds, will continue to protect The Gambia, guide its governance and enable its 95% Muslim population to hold firmly to Allah's Religion and continue to maintain its peace and goodwill, internally and with its international neighbours.
